Graphical abstract This review summarizes recent advances in the mechanisms, modification methods, and stability of WO x -based electrocatalysts, emphasizing their critical role in enhancing hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions for sustainable energy. Electrocatalysis plays a crucial role in the field of clean energy conversion and provides essential support for the development of eco-friendly technology. There is a pressing need for electrocatalysts in renewable energy systems that exhibit exceptional activity, selectivity, stability, and economic viability. The utilization of metal oxides as electrocatalysts for the process of water splitting has made substantial progress in both theoretical and practical aspects and has emerged as a widely explored field of research. Tungsten oxides (WO x ) have attracted much attention and are regarded as a highly promising electrocatalytic material due to their exceptional electrocatalytic activity, cost-effectiveness, and ability to withstand extreme conditions. This review introduces the fundamental mechanism of WO x -based electrocatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction and the oxygen evolution reaction, providing a comprehensive overview of recent research advancements in their modification. Factors contributing to the catalytic activity and stability of WO x are explored, highlighting their potential for industrial applications. The aim herein is to provide guidelines for the design and fabrication of WO x -based electrocatalysts, thereby facilitating further research on their mechanistic properties and stability improvements in water splitting. Keywords Non-stoichiometric tungsten oxide Electrocatalytic water splitting Modification Stability Oxygen vacancies 1 Introduction The shift towards clean and renewable energy sources is receiving heightened focus as fossil fuel reserves diminish and environmental concerns arise. Hydrogen is widely recognized as a very promising clean energy carrier for facilitating a transition to low-carbon energy in the industry. Green hydrogen production is often accomplished through the process of electrolyzing water. Due to the rapid advancement of energy storage methods, it is anticipated that sustainable energy sources like solar and wind power would be utilized to generate electricity for clean water splitting. This is because the direct conversion of solar energy to green hydrogen is hindered by its intermittent nature. To attain optimal efficiency in the production of green hydrogen within advanced and sustainable energy systems, it is crucial to develop and produce cost-effective catalysts that possess exceptional activity, adjustable product selectivity, and outstanding stability [1–5]. Electrocatalytic water splitting, which utilizes renewable electricity, is a very effective and low-carbon alternative for hydrogen production. This method has the potential to be applied in various fields and offers significant environmental benefits. By advocating for the advancement and use of electrocatalytic water splitting technology, carbon emissions can be effectively reduced in sectors such as transportation, aviation, industry, and building. This will greatly contribute to the objectives of sustainable development and the fight against climate change [6]. The cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are crucial events that occur during the process of electrochemical water splitting under mild operating conditions. Out of these options, electrocatalysts based on Pt were found to be the most efficient cathode for HER because of their ideal atomic hydrogen adsorption-free energy and exceptional surface polarizability. This leads to a high exchange current density and small Tafel slope values [7,8]. Ir and Ru-based catalysts were found to be the most effective for the OER. These catalysts provide active surface oxide layers that facilitate charge separation during the anodic process. Nevertheless, the utilization of these esteemed metal electrocatalysts in water splitting is typically constrained by their high cost and limited accessibility [9–11]. To overcome the thermodynamic obstacles associated with water splitting, particularly the need for a potential of 1.23 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) for OER, it is crucial to have electrocatalysts that show promise in reducing the excessive potentials necessary for water splitting [12,13]. The applied voltages enhance the kinetic barriers of the HER and OER, resulting in increased reaction rates and improved electrochemical energy conversion efficiency. Meanwhile, the use of active and stable electrocatalysts is anticipated to reduce the overvoltage and achieve high energy conversion efficiency [14,15]. Extensive research has been conducted on non-precious metal catalysts, including doped carbon materials, transition metal borides, carbides, hydroxides/hydroxyl oxides, phosphides, oxides, and single-atom catalysts, which are effective and durable options for efficient water splitting [16–20]. Nevertheless, most of the electrocatalysts now being developed for the HER and OER have significant effectiveness only at low levels of current densities (<200 mA cm−2) and for short durations (<100 h), posing a challenge in meeting the demanding demands of industrial water electrolysis. Hence, it is imperative to create electrocatalysts with exceptional efficiency that can sustain elevated activity and stability under high current densities. Transition metal oxides (TMOs) have been investigated as promising electrocatalysts for the HER because of their cost-effectiveness, abundant supply, and eco-friendliness. Nevertheless, it is important to acknowledge that the thermodynamic stability of the majority of TMOs in acidic conditions is restricted, except for a small number of iridium-based substances. The majority of TMOs electrocatalysts have limitations due to their low conductivity, slow reaction rates, inadequate hydrogen adsorption sites, and strong binding energy of atomic hydrogen [21–24]. Tungsten trioxides (WO3) have attracted considerable interest in diverse fields such as electrochromism, photoelectrocatalysis, photocatalysis, gas sensing, optical devices, and supercapacitors. These properties include their plentiful availability, eco-friendliness, excellent resistance to light degradation, high ability to conduct electrons, substantial distance over which holes can move, and outstanding catalytic performance [25–27]. However, the ability of WO3 nanomaterials to catalyze the process of water splitting is limited by their low electrical conductivity and insufficient hydrogen adsorption at the tungsten-oxygen active sites. Recently, tungsten oxides have two stoichiometric oxides, WO2 and WO3, and a variety of non-stoichiometric oxides (WO3− x ) with defects, such as W20O58 (WO2.9), W5O14 (WO2.8), W4O11 (WO2.75), W18O49 (WO2.72), W3O8 (WO2.67), W2O5 (WO2.5). These WO3− x materials exhibit higher conductivity, utilize straightforward synthesis procedures, and demonstrate improved stability in both acidic and alkaline settings [28–30]. WO x -based materials could be obtained by manipulating the reaction temperature and time [31,32]. The catalytic activity of WO x can be enhanced by altering its crystal structure, surface morphology, and surface electronic state. One effective method is through the introduction of oxygen vacancies (OVs), which can augment the number of active sites on the surface and enhance surface diffusivity, thereby facilitating electrochemical processes. Moreover, the catalytic activity of WO x -based electrocatalysts can be adjusted by modifying the crystal phase, morphology, and size of the materials [33]. By altering the composition and structure of WO x , one can effectively manipulate its catalytic activity and selectivity. Moreover, catalysts based on WO x demonstrate enhanced durability and resistance to corrosion when subjected to challenging conditions, such as the process of water splitting. Despite their exceptional electrocatalytic activity, WO x -based electrocatalysts have certain limitations. Tungsten is relatively rare and costly in comparison to other transition metals. Furthermore, the WO x with OVs can be oxidized to WO3 when subjected to heat and air, thus compromising their stability and lifetime [34]. The durability of catalysts is of utmost importance in industry, as it directly impacts the sustainability and dependability of the energy conversion processes. Hence, it is crucial to prioritize the stability of electrocatalysts while developing water-splitting systems that are more effective and energy-efficient. Fig. 1 shows an overview of the main topics covered herein. Efficient HER and OER activities have been observed for WO x materials during electrocatalytic water splitting in acidic and alkaline electrolytes, respectively. The OER process is initiated by the formation of OH* and O* species on the catalyst surface. Especially the abundant W–OH* and W–O* facilitate the initialization of reactions in alkaline electrolytes. However, the application of WO x catalysts is hindered by corrosion issues caused by their instability in acidic electrolytes [7,35]. In recent years, researchers have focused on improving the HER performance of WO x -based materials in neutral electrolytes, achieving promising results [36]. Chen et al. provided the latest advancements in the exploration of WO x electrocatalysts for HER and OER [37]. They systematically categorized these strategies into design principles that involve the manipulation of surface morphology, defect engineering, and synergistic catalysis. Besides, the preparation methods for modification of WO x -based catalysts by surface modification, heteroatom doping, heterojunction construction, and defect engineering were investigated for HER and the overall water splitting [38,39]. Zhang et al. introduced the structure and synthesis origin of W18O49 nanomaterials and provided an overview of their applications in electrochemistry, photocatalysis, near-infrared shielding, photothermal sensing, and other fields [40]. Stability analysis at industrial current density and reasons for poor material stability are seldom addressed in the published reviews of WO x for electrocatalytic water splitting. A diagram summarizing the content of this review is shown in Fig. 2 . This review primarily focuses on the mechanisms, modification methods, and stability of WO x -based electrocatalysts in the HER and the OER. In the HER, WO x -based electrocatalysts enhance hydrogen production by providing active sites that facilitate the adsorption and dissociation of protons. For the OER, these catalysts aid in oxygen production by offering active sites and managing the adsorption and dissociation of oxygen molecules. Understanding these mechanisms is crucial for the development of efficient WO x -based electrocatalysts. This review also emphasizes the role of morphological and crystal structure modifications, the creation of OVs, elemental doping, and composite structures in improving the performance and durability of these electrocatalysts. These modification techniques enhance surface chemical activity and electronic structure, leading to improved catalytic performance. Furthermore, the stability of WO x -based electrocatalysts is discussed, highlighting degradation mechanisms such as catalyst detachment, support material corrosion, impurity deposition, active site dissolution, and surface reconstruction. The review explores various strategies to enhance stability, including structural modulation and protective modifications. By examining the mechanisms, optimization strategies, and stability concerns, this review aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of how the structure of WO x -based electrocatalysts influences their catalytic activity. The potential for industrial applications of these electrocatalysts is significant. Continued research is expected to improve their stability and efficiency, thereby supporting the development of sustainable energy technologies. 2 Mechanisms of WO x -based electrocatalysts for HER and OER The electrochemical water splitting process can be described by the overall water splitting equation: H2O (l) → H2 (g) + 1/2O2 (g). This process involves two key half-reactions. Table 1 shows the reactions at both electrodes during water electrolysis in different electrolytes [41,42]. The HER occurs at the cathode, described by the equation: 2H+ (aq) + 2e−→ H2 (g). The OER takes place at the anode and is represented by: H2O (l) → 1/2O2 (g) + 2H+(aq) + 2e−. The enthalpy change for the overall water splitting reaction is 285.83 kJmol−1, reflecting the energy required to dissociate water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen gases under standard conditions [43]. The reaction mechanisms for the HER and OER vary in acidic and alkaline electrolytes depending on the chemical and electrical properties of the electrode surface. Fig. 3 (a) shows a concise overview of the mechanisms involved in the probable HER and OER in both acidic and alkaline electrolytes. M denotes the active site in the reaction. The HER is an easy reaction that involves adsorption, reduction, and desorption steps, as opposed to the more complex OER. The initial stage of the HER in both acidic and alkaline electrolytes involves the Volmer reaction, wherein hydrogen atoms are electrochemically adsorbed onto the active sites present on the surface of the electrode [44]. During this process, an M–H* bond is generated through the transfer of a single electron between the adsorbed hydrogen atom and the electrode surface. The H atoms that have been adsorbed can then undergo reduction through either the Heyrovsky or Tafel reaction, resulting in the production of H2 molecules that are then desorbed off the surface of the electrode. HER usually employs costly platinum group metals as catalysts in acidic electrolytes. Additionally, the use of acidic proton exchange membranes and strong acids as electrolytes is necessary, leading to increased expenses and potential concerns regarding safety and stability. Conversely, performing HER in alkaline electrolytes offers the advantages of lower cost and increased stability. Abundant transition metals including iron, cobalt, and nickel can be employed as catalysts to further decrease the cost. Nevertheless, the reduced speed of the reaction kinetics of HER in alkaline environments imposes restrictions on its practical utility [7,45]. The OER is a four-electron transfer mechanism that generates intermediates such as OH*, O*, and OOH*. Intermediate species M–OH*, M–O*, and M–OOH* are successively formed throughout the OER process in both acidic and alkaline environments. OER is primarily characterized by the ongoing oxidation of the active site, as well as the adsorption and desorption of intermediates that include oxygen. The transitions from M–OH* to M–O* and from M–O* to M–OOH* are classified as adsorption processes. The variation in adsorption energy between these two processes can serve as a measure of the OER's activity, with a combined energy of around 3.2 eV linked to the creation of M–O* from M–OH* and the regeneration of M–OOH* [46]. The efficiency of the OER is contingent upon the magnitude of the greatest energy barrier. If the energy barrier for the transition from M–OH* to M–O* is very low, then the energy barrier for the transition from M–O* to M–OOH* will be relatively high, and vice versa. Hence, M–O* serves as a crucial intermediary in the process of OER [47]. The OER reaction can be divided into four steps, with the step that has the largest energy barrier being the rate-limiting step. The adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) outlines the conversion of two water molecules into oxygen through four proton-electron transfer steps, with the deprotonation of OH* and the O–O coupling being the rate-determining steps due to their high energy barriers. In acidic OER, the energy required to overcome the H2O to OH* transition often corresponds to the deprotonation of OH* or the O–O coupling process [48–50]. For defect engineering materials, the active species generated by surface reconstruction and the dynamic evolution of active sites are not considered by the traditional AEM mechanism. For example, Wang et al. utilized the irreversible reconstruction behavior of cobalt-iron layered double hydroxides and the dynamic evolution of copper to construct a novel catalyst, namely CoFeCuOOH active species, and transformed the AEM mechanism into the oxygen-vacancy-site mechanism (OVSM) [51]. The OVSM takes into account the dynamic evolution of active sites during surface reconstruction and practical applications. Firstly, the valence states and coordination structures of Co, Fe, and Cu were determined through in-situ UV, in-situ Raman spectroscopy, and X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (XAFS), indicating the formation of Cu2S/CoFeCuOOH with high-valent metal species and proving the occurrence of irreversible reconstruction on the material surface. Subsequently, it was experimentally and theoretically demonstrated that the incorporation of Cu enhanced the covalency of the Co–O bond, forming ligand holes through intramolecular electron transfer, thereby enabling lattice oxygen to directly serve as active sites. Furthermore, they demonstrated the operation of the OVSM through pH dependence, tetramethylammonium hydroxide molecular probe, and in-situ electrochemical mass spectrometry [51]. The OVSM mechanism studies the atomic-level reconstruction of active sites during OER, activating and releasing lattice oxygen. This process reveals that half of the oxygen in the resulting O2 comes from lattice oxygen, offering key insights into catalytic active sites at the atomic scale. When examining the impact of pH and electrolyte type on catalysts, it is important to address the conditions of water splitting. Alkaline electrolysis tends to exhibit higher OER activity due to the presence of hydroxyl groups that facilitate the formation of M–OH and M–O intermediates, thus improving reaction kinetics. However, alkaline electrolysis faces significant challenges with HER at the cathode and generally has a lower efficiency, around 60%, which is a limitation for industrial applications [52,53]. In contrast, acidic electrolysis encounters difficulties with OER at the anode and requires more advanced equipment due to the high energy needed to break strong covalent bonds in water molecules and produce OH species, resulting in higher activation energy for OER. Despite these challenges, the reaction rates in acidic electrolysis are faster. Consequently, industrial hydrogen production primarily relies on alkaline electrolysis for its relative stability and cost-effectiveness, despite its lower overall efficiency [53,54]. Understanding the onset potentials of different reactions is of significant importance for both experimental research and industrial applications in electrochemical reactions. This section primarily explores the onset potentials of HER and OER when using different reference electrodes. According to relevant literature, when using the RHE, the onset potentials for HER and OER are 0 and 1.229 V, respectively [55]. The intrinsic properties of the RHE make it both suitable and ideal for experimental studies of these reactions. When RHE is used as the reference electrode, its zero potential and the onset potential of HER are identical, as they refer to the same phenomenon. When using the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) and successfully eliminating the liquid junction potential, the onset potentials for HER and OER are −0.118 and 1.111 V, respectively. In experimental research, SHE can serve as a reference electrode; however, due to differences in electrolyte concentration and composition between the laboratory environment and the SHE, a liquid junction potential can develop. Introducing a salt bridge can eliminate this potential, but it adds complexity to the experimental setup. If the same acidic or alkaline electrolyte solution is used in the working electrode and reference electrode compartments, RHE can be more conveniently employed. When using the standard silver-silver chloride electrode (E = 0.222 V) and successfully eliminating the liquid junction potential, the onset potentials for HER and OER are −0.340 and 0.889 V, respectively. The silver-silver chloride electrode is also a commonly used reference electrode. When the liquid junction potential is successfully eliminated, the silver-silver chloride electrode can provide reliable onset potential references for HER and OER. The presence of distinctive structural patterns that cause periodic disturbances in the crystal structure greatly affects the electronic structure of electrocatalysts. This leads to a preferential acceleration of reaction kinetics and an enhancement of the electrocatalytic performance in the production of H2 and O2. These structural designs increase the contact between reactive species and active species, while also improving conductivity to facilitate electron transfer. The enhancement of electrocatalytic performance is typically linked to the modification of the electronic structure, which includes many forms depicted in Fig. 3(b) [56]. The activity of the HER is strongly connected with the energy at which hydrogen is adsorbed. This energy is primarily determined by the electronic structure of the electrocatalyst's surface. Yang et al. conducted a thorough analysis of the most stable surfaces in two catalysts, WO3 (002) and H0.23WO3 (020), utilizing first-principles calculations [57]. According to the data presented in Fig. 3(c), the adsorption of H* on the WO3 (002) surface results in calculated ΔG H* values of −0.56 eV for the W site and −0.71 eV for the O site. This indicates that the W site is a more favorable active site for the HER process. As a result of the insertion of an interstitial hydrogen atom, there is a significant adsorption of hydrogen at the oxygen site on the surface of WO3 (002), but there is less pronounced adsorption at the oxygen site on the surface of H0.23WO3 (020). Introducing interstitial H atoms can greatly decrease the electron density of d-bond in active-site W atoms, leading to a decrease in hydrogen adsorption energy and weakening of W–H bonds on the surface of H0.23WO3 (020). This enables the quick and efficient removal of H* intermediates from the catalyst surface's active sites. Despite the progress made, further exploration of the mechanisms underlying WO x -based electrocatalysts remains crucial. More theoretical studies and experimental validations are needed to deeply understand the following aspects: precise identification and regulation of active sites, clarifying the specific impacts of different doping and defect engineering on active sites, and optimizing these sites to enhance catalytic performance; mechanisms of electronic structure regulation, investigating how doping and defects affect the electronic structure of WO x and their specific contributions to catalytic performance, thus providing more effective strategies for catalyst design and optimization; further understanding of interface effects, systematically studying the interface effects in heterostructures and core-shell structures to reveal the interaction mechanisms between different materials and optimize catalytic performance; and long-term stability studies, evaluating the stability and durability of WO x -based electrocatalysts during prolonged operation, and developing materials that can maintain high activity and stability. Previous theoretical studies have indicated that WO3 may not exhibit activity towards the OER due to its limited binding affinity towards OH [58]. Individuals enhance the activity of WO3 for OER by introducing doping and generating OVs. The activity of this process primarily depends on the OER energy, which is regulated by the contacts between the intermediates (OOH*, OH*, and O*) and the active sites on the catalyst's surface [59]. Therefore, the activity can be adjusted by making precise modifications to these interactions. Therefore, doping and vacancy engineering provide a viable approach to enhance the performance of WO x -based electrocatalysts [60]. That is achieved by altering the electronic structure and local coordination chemistry, which in turn affects the surface contacts. Li et al. discovered the Gibbs free energy of the fundamental step of OER and the overpotential of the enclosed Ir sites in the WO3 crystal matrix. Fig. 3(d) displays the 4e− mechanism and free energy diagrams of the proposed OER on Ir-doped WO3 [61]. The active sites in WO3 and Ir-doped WO3 are W and Ir atoms, respectively, located in the (110) crystal planes. The calculated free energy for the four fundamental stages on the (110) plate indicates that the reaction is primarily constrained by the transition from O* to OOH*, for both WO3 and Ir-doped WO3. The computed theoretical overpotential of Ir-doped WO3 (110) is 0.6 eV, somewhat lower than that of IrO2 (110) (0.64 eV) and substantially better than that of WO3 (110) (1.14 eV). This suggests that the presence of Ir-doped atoms greatly enhances the OER activity of WO3 (110). For instance, Liang et al. enhanced the catalytic activity of the OER by stabilizing the OH* species and increasing its binding affinity using vacancy engineering [62]. Given that the surface of WO3 is coated with a specific quantity of oxygen atoms and that the attachment of these negatively charged O2− groups is highly stronger, the removal of some surface oxygen atoms modifies the electronic arrangement of the surface W and consequently strengthens its connection to other negatively charged groups like OH*. Under acidic conditions, WO x is suitable as an electrocatalyst for both HER and OER, exhibiting good electrocatalytic activity and stability. Specifically, in acidic solutions, the HER primarily involves the reduction of protons to generate H2. WO3 surfaces can facilitate the adsorption and reduction of H+, making it effective for HER in acidic environments. Additionally, WO3 can catalyze the oxidation of water molecules to produce O2, thus demonstrating efficacy in OER under acidic conditions. Although the application of WO x in electrocatalysis has been extensively studied, the specific mechanisms by which it functions in catalytic processes remain incompletely understood. It is generally accepted that in high pH alkaline solutions, WO x dissolves at a relatively fast rate, which can affect its long-term stability as an electrocatalyst. Therefore, further experimental and theoretical investigations are needed to explore the dissolution kinetics and mechanisms of WO x under different alkaline conditions. Studies have shown that composite catalysts formed by WO x and other materials can significantly reduce the dissolution rate of WO x in alkaline media through synergistic effects. Experimental data indicate that WO3 shows high electrocatalytic activity for HER in alkaline environments. For instance, data from M. Anik's article show high current density at pH = 9 and higher pH values, supporting effectiveness of WO3 in alkaline HER [63]. In alkaline conditions, WO3 may be suitable as an electrocatalyst for HER. However, WO3 tends to dissolve at high pH, forming tungstate ions (WO4 2−), which leads to the deactivation of the catalyst. The dissolution reaction is as follows: WO3(s) + 2OH− → WO4 2− + H2O. Given that WO3 or WO3− x gradually dissolves in alkaline electrolyte [36], researchers are considering conducting HER and OER in a neutral electrolyte [64]. To address the issue of catalyst dissolution, several strategies can be employed. Adjusting the nanostructure of the catalyst (e.g., nanoparticles, nanowires, or nanosheets) can enhance its stability, thereby reducing the likelihood of dissolution [65]. For instance, literature reports that nanostructured WO x can significantly enhance its electrocatalytic performance and stability. Chen et al. demonstrated that employing a W/WO2 heterostructure can markedly improve the catalyst's stability and HER activity in an alkaline electrolyte, showing ultra-low overpotential and a small Tafel slope, indicating good electrocatalytic performance in an alkaline environment [66]. Introducing additional metal elements to form alloys can improve stability by lowering the dissolution potential of the catalyst [67,68]. Studies have shown that combining WO3 with other metals such as W or Mo can significantly enhance its stability and electrocatalytic activity in alkaline electrolytes. Perović et al. found that adding WO4 2− as a third component to a Co-Mo electrocatalytic system can significantly boost HER activity in an alkaline electrolyte, exhibiting lower energy consumption and good catalytic performance at high current densities [69]. Enhancing the dissolution resistance of the catalyst by modifying its electronic structure (e.g., doping with different elements) is another approach [70,71]. For example, doping heterogeneous elements has been reported to significantly alter the electronic structure of WO3, thereby improving its dissolution resistance. Strengthening the interaction between the catalyst and the support, such as using highly stable support materials (e.g., carbon nanotubes, alumina, or titania), can also enhance catalyst stability [72,73]. Additionally, introducing sacrificial metal elements that oxidize and dissolve preferentially can protect the main active sites of the catalyst [74]. For instance, studies have shown that the introduction of sacrificial metals can effectively safeguard the primary active sites of WO3, thus enhancing its stability. Coating the catalyst surface with a protective film (e.g., conductive polymers or metal oxides) can prevent dissolution [75]. Literature indicates that applying a protective film on the catalyst surface can significantly improve its stability in alkaline solutions. Optimizing operational conditions (e.g., electrolyte composition, operating temperature, current density) can reduce catalyst dissolution [76]. For example, adjusting these conditions can significantly reduce the dissolution of WO3 without compromising catalytic efficiency. Moreover, controlling reaction conditions (e.g., lowering the operating potential or current density) can minimize excessive oxidation or reduction of the catalyst, thereby preventing dissolution. Research shows that precise control of reaction conditions can effectively inhibit catalyst dissolution and extend its lifespan [77]. By employing these strategies, the stability and efficacy of WO x in alkaline environments should be improved, thereby addressing its dissolution issue in high-concentration KOH solutions. 3 Modification methods for WO x -based electrocatalysts Based on the above discussion on the electrocatalytic mechanism of WO x , there are several strategies to enhance its catalytic performance in electrocatalysis. These include increasing the number of active sites, making surface modifications, enhancing electron transfer, and optimizing the crystal structure. Various modification methods have been explored to improve their intrinsic activity and optimize efficiency and stability in electrocatalytic reactions. For example, modulation of the morphology and crystal engineering of WO x -based materials affects the band gap energy, enabling their application in electrocatalysis devices. The manipulation of morphology and crystal structure can control active site exposure and protons or oxygen adsorption capacity, thereby enhancing electrocatalytic HER and OER performance. Moreover, doping with noble or non-precious metals, cooperating with conductive supports, and compositing hybrid materials were expected to promote electron transfer, reducing the activation energy for reactions with enlarged surface area and enhanced surface dipole moment and stability. Among these, the interfacial engineering of heterojunctions and core-shell structure design offers favorable interfacial interactions for higher charge separation and reinforces the defect-resistant properties of catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . The data on electrolyte, catalytic activity, and stability of various WO x -based electrocatalysts for HER and OER are presented in Tables 2 and 3 . In addition, theoretical models have demonstrated the potential of defect-rich WO x for accelerated HER and OER kinetics due to enhanced surface dipole moment. Density functional theory (DFT) computations have been investigated for a better understanding of the extraordinary electrocatalytic activity of WO3− x [78,79]. Based on the above-mentioned strategies, combinations of various modification strategies have been studied to improve the catalytic activity and stability of WO x -based materials. 3.1 Morphology and crystal structure control The electrocatalyst's morphology and crystal structure are crucial for its performance. Precisely controlling these issues allows for manipulating reactant ion adsorption and gaseous product diffusion, thereby enhancing the catalyst's efficiency [80]. Within the realm of morphology engineering strategies, nano-array configurations [81], and porous structures [82] have been extensively utilized in the design and synthesis of WO x -based electrocatalysts. Nano-array configurations enlarge the exposed surface area of active sites, consequently improving the catalyst's apparent activity. On the other hand, porous structures increase the catalyst's surface area and facilitate the rapid detachment of bubbles, thereby enhancing mass diffusion. The electrocatalytic performance of WO x can be enhanced by judiciously regulating the morphology and surface crystal structure. Morphologies and crystal structures can be varied via the different growth conditions from hydrogen reduction, thermal decomposition, hydrothermal, solvent thermal, vapor phase deposition, electrodeposition methods, and so on [83,84]. The different morphologies of WO3 samples significantly affect the exposure of their crystal planes and catalytic activity, as shown in Fig. 5 (a and b). By adjusting the annealing and calcination conditions, the nanostructure of WO3 can be optimized to enhance its electrocatalytic performance. Specifically, annealing can lead to a transformation from stacked nanorods to nanowires, while increased calcination time can result in more complex nanorod structures. These morphological changes directly influence the number and type of exposed crystal planes (such as the (002) plane), thereby optimizing the active sites for catalytic reactions [85,86].The preparation of WO x with different shapes/dimensions, such as nanowires, nanorods, and nanosheets, has been achieved by altering the pH value and precipitation rate [87,88]. Recently, M. Ahangarkani proposed a thermochemical process to synthesize sub-micron WO x particles [89]. This process resulted in the transformation of initial micron-sized polygonal W particles into cauliflower-like WO3 structures, which further evolved into needle-like WO2 structures, and finally into sub-micron cubic W particles. The size of the initial W powder was significantly reduced as a result of the formation of needle-like WO x particles after the vacuum heat treatment. Additionally, the study observed the formation of cauliflower-like WO x structures, a phase transition from yellow WO x to brown WO x after the vacuum treatment, and the growth of W clusters during the hydrogen reduction process [90]. Various WO x nanostructures have been successfully synthesized using different methods, such as the utilization of air-oxidized W wires and in-situ evaporating on silicon wafers to produce WO3 nanorods/nanobelts [91], infrared irradiation heating of W films under varying vacuum conditions to prepare single-crystalline W18O49 nanotubes or nanowires on Ta substrates [92], thermal evaporation of W powders on carbon cloth to grow WO x nanowire arrays [93], non-aqueous colloidal synthesis of WO x nanowires [94], and in-situ growth of WO2.72 nanowires on a substrate by a simple solvothermal reaction [95,96]. In particular, WO x materials possess unique physical and chemical properties after modification. The nanowires and nanorods exhibit excellent catalytic activity and stability and are particularly useful for electrocatalytic water splitting. Liu et al. reported the synthesis of ultra-long WO x /C nanowires (denoted as WO x /C NWs) with a high concentration of OVs by a two-step method using dopamine and ammonium tetrathiogungstate as precursors via calcination[97]. The obtained WO x /C self-supporting NWs exhibited the HER overpotential of 108 mV at 10 mA cm−2 with a Tafel slope of 46 mV dec−1 and no significant current density decrease after 1000 cycles. The large surface area and high electron mobility of nanoplates also make them ideal candidates for photoelectrochemical water splitting [38]. The growth orientation under various preparation conditions brings different dimensional nanostructures; among those, one-dimensional (1D) structures such as nanorods, nanowires, and nanofibers facilitate the rapid transfer of electrons along the longitudinal direction [98,99]. The obtained hybridized material has a uniform and ultra-long 1D nanowire structure with high surface roughness, which effectively increases the specific surface area and improves electron mobility via the carbon substrate. The two-dimensional (2D) structure favors the exposure of specific crystalline facets to provide large electron-electrolyte interfaces [100]. The exposure of specific crystal facets in 1D or 2D nanostructures facilitates the optimization of the unique optical, magnetic, and electrical properties of catalysts with enlarged surface areas and cross-sections for absorption, resulting in enhanced activity [101]. Low-dimensional tungsten oxide-based catalysts can improve the catalytic activity of reactions such as water splitting at high current densities by enhancing the electron transfer process. In addition, the surface electronic structure and the number of coordinated unsaturated atoms of the catalyst can be optimized by modulating the particle size, strain, defects, and ligand effects [102–104]. Zhu et al. and He et al. emphasized the enhancement of electrocatalytic performance through the modulation of surface properties and intercalation of metal nitrides and multidimensional structures [105,106]. These methods are also applicable to WO x -based electrocatalysts, where adjusting surface characteristics and structural optimization can improve their activity and stability. Highly efficient anisotropic electron transfer occurs on the surface of 3D structures. Spherical WO3 nanoparticles were prepared using chitosan biopolymers as templates, which showed a 4-fold increase in activity over WO3 nanoparticles. The observed enhancement in catalytic activity can be attributed to the unique structure and morphology of spherical WO3 nanoparticles. The spherical configuration potentially offers a larger specific surface area and an increased number of active sites by active crystal facet growing, thereby improving the efficiency of the catalytic reaction. Moreover, the morphology of the spherical particles may facilitate improved electron transport and proton conduction properties, further enhancing the catalytic activity [107]. WO3 exhibits various crystal structures at different temperatures. The most desirable crystal structure of WO3 is a cubic chalcogenide structure, where a W-centered octahedron with six O vertices (WO6) is arranged in an orderly manner. Other structures can be obtained by tilting or rotating the basic unit cell of the cubic-phase WO3. Within the temperature range of −273.15 to 926.85 °C, WO3 can undergo a minimum of eight phase transitions. The monoclinic phase I (ε-WO3) remains stable only at low temperatures below −43 °C. The triclinic phase (δ-WO3) remains stable within the temperature range of −43 to 17 °C. The monoclinic phase II (γ-WO3) remains stable within the temperature range of 17 to 330 °C. The temperature range of stability for the orthorhombic phase (β-WO3) is from 330 to 740 °C, whereas the tetragonal phase (α-WO3) is stable at temperatures ranging from 740 to 900 °C, as shown in Fig. 5(c) [108–110]. Xiong et al. demonstrated that optimizing hydrogen adsorption kinetics through phase evolution can significantly enhance catalytic performance [111]. This provides a new perspective for understanding the reaction mechanisms in WO x -based catalysts, particularly in optimizing active sites and reaction pathways. Researchers explored different crystal phases (such as hexagonal, monoclinic, orthorhombic, and triclinic, as shown in Fig. 5d) and the catalytic properties of these phases under various lattice exposure conditions. By adjusting annealing conditions and introducing oxygen vacancies, researchers significantly altered the crystal structure and catalytic performance of WO3. Hexagonal WO3 can transform into monoclinic WO3 under high-temperature annealing conditions, accompanied by the formation of oxygen vacancies. These OVs can significantly enhance the performance of the electrochemical HER [85]. Hexagonal and monoclinic WO3 nanorods and nanosheets synthesized via hydrothermal methods exhibit different morphologies and catalytic properties under various annealing conditions. Studies have shown that hexagonal WO3 nanorods gradually transform into monoclinic WO3 nanosheets under high-temperature conditions, and this morphological change is accompanied by improved catalytic activity [85,112]. Mohamed et al. reported the preparation of hexagonal WO3 nanotubes by hydrothermal and sonication methods using inorganic salts such as ammonium ferrous sulfate and cobalt chloride under different reaction conditions and sonication times [113]. The heterojunction between hexagonal and monoclinic WO3 has been proven to effectively promote charge separation, further enhancing catalytic performance [86]. Fang et al. directly prepared cubic phase WO3− x nanosheet by reducing H2WO4·H2O under 10% H2/90% N2 mixture gas at 500 °C, which has a highly symmetric crystal structure and a large number of OVs, with a HER overpotential of 294 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 60 mV dec−1, and possesses good electrocatalytic stability, effective photothermal conversion and good resistance to photobleaching [114]. The triclinic and monoclinic II phases of WO3 are the two most commonly occurring phase transitions at lower temperatures among these structures. Both of these phases exhibit thermodynamic stability and possess distinct physicochemical characteristics. 3.2 Defect engineering The rational construction of defects in electrocatalysts enables the modulation of electronic structure and the adjustment of adsorption energies of reaction intermediates by enhancing surface dipole moment, thereby enhancing the performance of water electrolysis [116]. Vacancies can also be used as locations for adsorbing guest ions, increasing the specific capacity of the material. By adsorbing and embedding ions, the vacancies can hold more ions and increase the energy storage capacity of the electrochemical material [117]. Defect engineering has sparked great interest in electrocatalysis as an avenue to develop more efficient and sustainable nanocatalysts [118]. The removal of oxygen atoms in tungsten oxide causes lattice disorder and the formation of low-valence metal ions, which has a substantial impact on its band structure and characteristics. Oxygen atom removal not only changes the structural arrangement but also modifies the local oxidation states. Furthermore, non-stoichiometric tungsten oxide frequently exhibits geometric channels that serve as efficient ion transport paths, such as h-WO3 [119]. Pristine stoichiometric ratio oxides usually exhibit unfavorable HER activity. The introduction of OVs into WO3 has been reported as one of the most effective methods to enhance intrinsic catalytic activity by modulating electronic structure, conductivity, and hydrogen adsorption energy by enhancing surface dipole moment [120–123]. For example, WO2.72 significantly impacts the performance and application of electrocatalysis in a wide range of applications. WO2.72 is a monoclinic crystal with an asymmetric and non-stoichiometric structure. It contains around the trigonal-coordinated oxygen atoms at the edges of the unit cell. Additionally, WO2.72 possesses a unique three-dimensional channel structure [124]. These structural features, along with the presence of surface OVs, facilitate strong interactions with reactants and efficient electron transfer within the oxide lattice. Consequently, WO2.72 is considered a promising candidate material for electrocatalysis [125]. However, DFT calculations have revealed that structurally stable WO2.72 exhibits a significant overpotential in the catalytic HER, which may limit its catalytic activity. To enhance the catalytic performance of TMOs, a promising strategy involves modulating the anionic or cationic sites within the metal-based compounds within a certain limit of defect concentration. For example, introducing high-valence non-3d transition metal ions (e.g., W6+) as low-activity sites in WO2.72 allows for effective tuning of the electron configuration of the 3d transition metal cations [126]. This modulation can alter the material's electronic structure and reaction activity by changing band energy and enhancing its catalytic performance. This approach can potentially optimize the catalytic activity of WO2.72, making it a more promising candidate material for electrocatalysis. It should be noted that the aforementioned methods and strategies are based on current scientific research and theoretical calculations, and further experimental validation and optimization are required to confirm their effectiveness and feasibility. The OVs in WO x -based materials have been studied to modify the local oxidation state and contribute to property tuning, thus regulating the conductivity, surface electronic structure, and binding energy for reactions with intermediates. The resulting low potential and enhanced intrinsic activity for HER in acidic media were explored [34,127,128]. Besides, with increasing the concentration of OVs in anode materials, the charge transfer capability was improved and the energy barrier of the oxygen intermediate containing the active sites was reduced depending on the modulation of the intrinsic electronic states. Various methods have been investigated to introduce OVs, such as heat treatment under the H2/Ar atmosphere, CO, carbothermal reduction, sodium borohydride reduction, phosphine reduction, plasma-induced vacancy engineering, and solvothermal methods [34,129]. Due to its restricted active sites, high H* adsorption free energy, and low electrical conductivity, WO3 is not a good choice as a substrate material for electrocatalysis. To address these limitations, researchers have conducted thorough defect engineering, particularly focusing on reducing the levels of oxygen and tungsten in WO3, intending to enhance its catalytic activity and stability. The undesirable ΔG H* at the W-site of WO3 has been reported to be responsible for its poor activity towards HER in acidic media; therefore, tuning the local structure of WO3 at the atomic level is prospective in improving the HER activity and various applications [130]. Additionally, the introduction of OVs in Pt/def-WO3@CFC catalysts has been explored to enhance HER performance [131]. The presence of OVs in the WO3 matrix promotes the catalytic activity and stability of Pt-based catalysts. Pt/def-WO3@CFC catalysts demonstrate superior electrocatalytic performance, comparable to commercial Pt/C catalysts, while offering enhanced mass activity and electrochemical stability, as shown in Fig. 6 (a). In conclusion, recent developments in Pt-based catalysts for HER have revealed significant advancements in terms of activity, stability, and reduced noble metal usage. Strategies such as doping Pt into WO x structures, immobilizing Pt single atoms on WO3 nanosheets, and introducing OVs have led to improved catalytic performance. The excellent HER performance of Pt/def-WO3@CFC is due to the synergistic catalytic effects between Pt atom clusters and def-WO3. The OVs can make Pt more stable and help it spread out more in WO3@CFC. Li et al. utilized wet grinding and heat treatment methods to activate WO3, resulting in the formation of dark blue WO2.9 [132]. This activated catalyst was examined for its efficacy in the HER within an acidic electrolytic water environment. An extended ordered defect structure is formed in WO3, leading to the preferential exposure of the electronically structurally modified W-site and enhanced catalytic activity for HER, as shown in Fig. 6(b). The additional electronic states in WO2.9 make the Fermi level 0.70 eV higher than that of WO3, indicating that the minimum of the conduction band of WO2.9 is more positive, which makes it easier to accept electrons. The WO2.9 facilitates the adsorption and reaction of reducing agents on the surface of catalysts. As investigated in Fig. 6(c and d), Zheng et al. have introduced abundant OVs into WO3 nanosheets for high conductivity and enlarged active surface area using liquid phase exfoliation [127]. The density of states (DOS) of bulk WO3 exhibits typical semiconductor features, and the computed ΔG H* at the W sites approximates 2.3 eV, denoting inert W sites in bulk WO3. However, DFT simulations show that the introduction of OVs in WO3 makes it promising for HER. In addition, Wu et al. reported a new “oxygen extraction” method for the synthesis of less toxic metal WO2-carbon mesoporous nanowires (denoted as MWCMN) with a high concentration of OVs by an inorganic-organic hybridization strategy [133]. The unique electronic structure, large number of active centers created by the highly concentrated OVs, and tight bonding with carbon materials made active and stable WO3 catalysts with a narrowed band gap, and the free energy of hydrogen adsorption close to zero. Wondimu et al. concentrated on developing an effective electrocatalyst for HER by utilizing a nanocomposite of phosphine-reduced iron-doped tungsten oxide and reduced graphene oxide (Fe-WO x P/rGO) [134]. The electrocatalytic activity of the Fe-WO x P/rGO nanocomposite was remarkable, surpassing that of conventional catalysts. The increased activity was ascribed to the synergistic interaction between the OVs generated on the WO x nanoplates and the conductive rGO nanosheets, which facilitated the HER. The nanocomposite exhibited exceptional stability and conductivity, rendering it a highly attractive contender for hydrogen production. Collectively, these findings show the capability of the doped WO x -based materials as effective electrocatalysts for the HER. Specifically, the presence of OVs helps to provide active sites and catalytic activity, thereby increasing the reaction rate of the Fe-WO x P/rGO electrocatalyst. The OER performance of OVs engineering WO3 has also been studied and improved for unique electronic structure, increased number of active centers, and enhanced conductivity. For instance, Diao et al. prepared an OVs-rich WO3 nanowire-array-nanosheet-array (WO3 NWA-NSA) on nickel foam (NF) by a facile hydrothermal method for improved OER activity, as shown in Fig. 6(e) [81]. Liang et al. introduced OVs in WO3 by plasma sputtering and the improved OER performance was also demonstrated through DFT calculations [62]. As investigated in Fig. 6(f and g), the binding affinity of intermediate OH* species during OER was adjusted by the defective-WO3 with more active sites, resulting in accelerated surface reaction kinetics and enhanced OER catalytic activity. The improved electrical conductivity of OVs-WO3 was ascribed to the increased number of charge carriers in the electronic states near the Fermi level [135]. 3.3 Elemental doping The role of noble metal doping in WO x for electrocatalytic HER and OER has been extensively studied. Noble metals such as platinum (Pt), iridium (Ir), and rhodium (Rh) significantly enhance catalytic activity and stability through their interaction and synergistic effects with WO x [136–139]. WO x provides a large surface area and abundant defect sites, thereby increasing the loading and density of active sites for noble metals. This interaction also modifies the electronic structure, charge transport, and chemical environment, thereby enhancing catalytic efficiency. Doping with foreign elements significantly improves the d-orbital electronic structure of the catalyst, thereby enhancing its catalytic activity. Cationic doping can break the scaling relationship of reaction intermediates, achieving better OER activity. Anionic doping also significantly affects the electronic state of active sites [48]. Heteroatom doping in WO x enhances the catalytic performance of HER and OER by improving the electronic structure and increasing the density of active sites. This synergistic effect is crucial for achieving high catalytic activity and stability. Studies have shown that the Pt-WO3− x @rGO catalysts demonstrate improved catalytic performance due to the synergistic effect between Pt and WO x [140]. These catalysts exhibit enhanced electron transfer, reduced activation energy, and increased stability. Another significant advancement lies in the immobilization of Pt single atoms (Pt-SA) on WO3 nanosheets [135]. The Pt-SA/ML-WO3 catalysts exhibit excellent electrocatalytic properties for HER, including low overpotential, high turnover frequency, and long-term stability as shown in Fig. 7 . The unique interaction between Pt single atoms and the WO3 support contributes to the catalyst's superior performance. Furthermore, the choice of support materials has a significant impact on the performance of Pt-based catalysts. Comparisons between carbon-supported Pt-SA and Pt nanoparticles supported on WO3− x have revealed that Pt-SA/WO3− x catalysts exhibit enhanced hydrogen spillover and improved Pt mass activity for HER [141]. This highlights the crucial role of support materials in optimizing catalyst performance. Liu et al. presents a catalyst consisting of WO3 doped with a single atom of Ru [136]. This catalyst has outstanding HER activity and stability in acidic, alkaline, and neutral environments, requiring minimal overpotentials. As shown in Fig. 8 , the Ru-WO3 electrocatalyst exhibits superior HER activity with an ultralow overpotential of 17.6 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and the smallest Tafel slop of 16.8 mV dec−1 in alkaline solution. The higher performance of the system is attributed to its defective oxygen and electron transport processes. Li et al. investigated the immobilization of ruthenium single atoms (Ru SAs) into a structure resembling the oxygen vacancy of urchin-like tungsten trioxide as shown in Fig. 9 (a) [137]. The results exhibit the minimal overpotentials for the HER under acidic, alkaline, and neutral environments. Similarly, Pi et al. examined sub-nanometric ruthenium clusters supported on WO x nanowires (Ru SNC/W18O49 NWs) as shown in Fig. 9(b) [138]. This catalyst exhibits significant electrocatalytic efficacy for the HER in acidic conditions. The performance of this catalyst is comparable to that of platinum catalysts due to factors such as strong metal-support contact, electron-deficient Ru clusters, and proton transport capabilities. Nguyen et al. reported the utilization of Rh-based WO3 electrocatalysts for the process of HER in acidic, alkaline, and alkaline-seawater electrolytes [139]. Rh-WO3 demonstrates excellent performance with small overpotentials and remarkable durability, even under demanding alkaline-seawater conditions. In summary, while noble metals provide excellent active sites, WO x plays a vital role in enhancing their performance through structural support, increased active site density, and electronic modifications. This synergistic relationship is key to achieving high catalytic activity and stability in OER and HER applications. The interaction of Pt [140] or Ir [142,143] with WO x also plays an important role in the electrocatalytic OER. WO x as a carrier can provide high surface area and active sites to promote the adsorption and dissociation of oxygen molecules. The loading of noble metals can provide the active center of the catalyst to promote the electrochemical reduction of oxygen and oxygen release reaction. The catalyst consists of active centers in the form of high-valence Ir sites and a matrix made of acid-stable WO3 [142]. Recent research has found that oxygen-deficient black WO3− x NF support enhances the HER by providing increased electronic conductivity and favorable nucleation sites for Ir loading [57]. The researchers utilized theoretical calculations to devise the catalyst and discovered that the extensively oxidized Ir sites have a vital function in enhancing the adsorption energies of pivotal intermediates engaged in the OER. The Ir sites can be stabilized within the WO3 matrix. The experimental findings showed that the Ir:WO3/Ir catalyst displayed a significant mass activity of 13.8 A mgIr −1 at 10 mA cm−2 and maintained outstanding stability in 0.5 M H2SO4 for a duration of 32 days. The outstanding performance is due to the stabilized high-valence Ir sites that have been optimized to have the ideal binding energies with oxygen species. The study emphasizes the catalyst's ability to be both cost-effective and robust, making it an efficient catalyst for PEM electrolyzers. WO x were doped with Ni, a non-precious metal, to enhance their electrocatalytic performance in water splitting reactions [144]. The significance of Ni doping in enhancing the catalytic efficiency of the OER and HER has been demonstrated. Several investigations have demonstrated exceptional performance in terms of OER, surpassing that of commercial iridium catalysts, by synthesizing nanorods of Ni x WO2.72 in a 0.1 M KOH solution [144]. These interfaces increased the number of active sites and improved the oxidation/reduction performance. The study also revealed that the introduction of sulfur and nickel atoms in Ni0.4WO3− x S x nanorods increased the number of OVs and electrical conductivity [145]. This led to the formation of significant active sites, which exhibited OER performance comparable to that of commercial Pt catalysts. Furthermore, the serrated Ni-WO3 electrodes [146], fabricated using a straightforward in-situ etching technique, experienced a self-reconfiguration phenomenon while undergoing the OER, resulting in a significant enhancement in their catalytic efficiency. In the field of electrocatalysis, elemental doping-induced lattice compression significantly enhances catalytic performance. Doping elements, due to their smaller atomic radius, cause a reduction in the lattice constant of the host material, thereby affecting electron distribution and surface active sites. Ni-doped W18O49​ nanorod arrays, with their unique amorphous-crystalline interfaces, significantly enhance the catalytic efficiency for both OER and HER, as shown in Fig. 9(c) [125]. Researchers employed a highly interconnected Ni/WO x /NF porous nanosheet array configuration to successfully facilitate both HER and OER with minimal overpotential as shown in Fig. 9(d) [147]. This was achieved by increasing the number of active sites and adjusting interfacial characteristics. Studies have shown that Ni doping increases the number of oxygen vacancies, as confirmed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope (HRTEM), leading to a substantial improvement in electrocatalytic water splitting performance due to the induced lattice compression and associated electronic structure modifications. Similarly, The lattice compression of WO2.7− x doped with Co and Ni has been verified by XRD and TEM. Huang et al. demonstrated that Co-doped WO2.7− x exhibits the lowest energy barrier under alkaline conditions, requiring only 59 mV of overpotential to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2, as shown in Fig. 9(e) [148]. This lattice compression optimizes the surface electronic structure and the distribution of active sites, significantly reducing the energy barrier for water splitting reactions and enhancing catalytic efficiency. Furthermore, Liu et al. investigated single-atom Co-doped WO3, which demonstrated exceptional electrocatalytic performance across all pH levels and remarkable durability, as shown in Fig. 9(f) [149]. High-angle angular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) imaging and computational results revealed that Co doping optimizes adsorption energies and enhances electrical conductivity, thereby significantly improving the catalytic activity of WO3. Similarly, Chen et al. investigated catalysts composed of cobalt and iron co-doped tungsten oxide (Co&Fe-WO2.72) [150]. The co-doping method enhanced the stability of alkaline conditions and the presence of surface hydroxyl groups, leading to higher electrocatalytic activity and increased efficiency in converting solar energy to hydrogen. This trend is good for the OER because it can use high-valence metal oxide as an active site. What makes it more stable, though, is that the W valence state is getting smaller. Lattice compression or stretching effects induced by elemental doping play a vital role in modifying the catalytic properties. For instance, introducing Mn or V into the WO3 lattice results in local lattice distortions, which can either compress or stretch the lattice structure. These distortions influence the electronic environment and the interaction between the catalyst and reactants [151]. Specifically, optimal Mn and V doping concentrations reduce the overpotential required to reach 10 mA cm−2 by 97 and 38 mV, respectively. Previous studies by Li et al. and Zheng et al. reported similar effects on the stretching vibrations of WO3, highlighting this property as a promising strategy for enhancing material performance [132,152]. These findings suggest a promising strategy for designing highly active, non-precious electrocatalysts for green energy conversion applications. Collectively, these studies introduce novel approaches and techniques for developing cost-effective and highly efficient catalysts made from non-precious metals for water-splitting electrocatalysis. By optimizing the electronic structure, morphology, and surface properties, significant improvements in electrocatalytic activity, stability, and conductivity have been achieved. These findings contribute substantially to advancements in sustainable energy conversion and storage [153]. 3.4 Hybrid composite materials The heterostructures in WO x -based and the core-shell structures substantially impact the electrocatalytic activity and stability. Interface effects in electrocatalysis can boost the adsorption and activation of reactants on the catalyst surface, enhancing the reaction rate. The interaction between reactants and catalysts can be improved by creating WO x composite catalysts with appropriate interface structures, catalytic activity, and efficiency. For example, mixing different catalyst nanoparticles to produce interface regions can result in synergistic effects that promote reactant transfer and reaction at the interface. Furthermore, core-shell structures can improve the electrocatalytic performance of WO x hybrid composites. The shell provides better stability, preventing catalyst deactivation and corrosion, and can also tune the reaction rate and selectivity by controlling the properties and structure of the shell. The utilization of WO x hybrid composite electrocatalysts with interface effects and core-shell structures can optimize the catalytic activity, stability, and selectivity for the HER and OER, enabling control and optimization of the catalytic activity of hybrid composite electrocatalysts and advancing the application of electrocatalysis in energy conversion and sustainable development fields. 3.4.1 Heterostructures Interface effects include heterostructures, heterojunction interfaces, and Mott-Schottky heterojunction interfaces, in which electrons are rearranged to form more active centers. The diverse interfacial electronic structures can optimize the chemical adsorption ability of catalysts, thereby further enhancing the kinetics of both the HER and OER [154,155]. The interfacial bonding between different components enhances the electron transfer rates and regulates the conductivity, hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity, chemical stability, and active site density, resulting in synergistic effects. The different chemical compositions and crystal structures in heterostructures induce lattice strains by rearranging atoms that affect intermediates' adsorption energy, improving catalytic activity through strain effects. Additionally, heterostructure materials change in electronic structure across their interfaces, which can be regarded as electronic interactions [156]. Surface electron modulation is related to charge transfer across the hetero-interfaces, which occurs through the interface until the work function is equal. Modifying heterostructures through chemical and physical methods can further optimize their electronic structure and charge transport/mass transfer properties, improving catalytic performance [157–160]. The heterostructures of WO x show excellent performance and broad application prospects in the field of catalysis, and the rational design and modulation of the heterostructures of tungsten oxide can significantly improve its catalytic performance and electrochemical activity. The superior performance of the following heterostructures is mainly attributed to the synergistic effect and interfacial enhancement between different components. For instance, Wang et al. employed a two-step heat treatment procedure to synthesize the material [161]. The WS2/WO2.9/C membrane has exceptional performance in acidic solutions as an electrode for the HER. The low Tafel slope and high onset potential of the system can be due to the synergistic effect of the ternary system and the improved coupling between the W-based nanostructures and the conductive carbon substrate. The diverse composition of WS2 possesses promising prospects for utilization in highly efficient hydrogen generation systems. In a comparable investigation, Cho et al. introduced nanocrystallized 1 T-WS2 combined with WO3 to promote the transport of protons to the active site and thus improve the performance of the HER [162]. The synthesis of this heterostructure entails sulfidating a tungsten layer to produce nanocrystalline 1 T-WS2, and subsequently oxidizing it to create amorphous WO3 (a-WO3), resulting in a 1 T-WS2/a-WO3 bulk heterointerface. The presence of a hydrophilic interface in WO3 facilitates the hydrogen spillover effect, enabling the transport of adsorbed protons from a-WO3 to 1 T-WS2. The studies showed that WO3 exhibited a greater rate of proton adsorption compared to the initial proton adsorption and had a larger binding energy. On the other hand, the 1 T-WS2 phase displayed a decreased overpotential for the HER [163]. The WC heterostructure is created by manipulating the phases and introducing heteroatoms, resulting in the formation of flawed structures, as shown in Fig. 10 (a). Additionally, a-WO x /WC heterostructure exhibits promising catalytic activity in the HER. The heterostructure present on the surface of the WC material plays a crucial role in the process of HER and demonstrates a significant level of reactivity. The heterostructure exhibits outstanding HER performance in both acidic and neutral electrolytes, characterized by little overpotential and elevated current density. The existence of the heterostructure surface reduces the adsorption of HER intermediates on WC, and the oscillations in bias excitation of the surface oxide/carbide heterostructure are related to the HER activity. Integrating multi-components with different functions into a hybrid electrocatalyst through interface engineering has been regarded as a practical approach to achieving efficient bi-functional HER/OER [164,165]. Xiong et al. demonstrated the importance of constructing hetero-interfaces between nickel nitride and vanadium oxynitride to enhance catalytic performance, which is similar to the hetero-interface modulation strategies in WO x -based catalysts [166]. By optimizing the interfaces, significant improvements in catalytic activity and charge transfer efficiency can be achieved. Recent articles combining the noble metal Ru with transition metal oxides WO x to build interfacial structures have exploited their interactions and synergistic effects to improve the efficiency of electrocatalytic water splitting reactions [156]. Peng et al. discovered that a uniform distribution of Ru induces better electron transfer on the Ru-WO2.72 Schottky barrier by lowering the energy barrier at the interface, resulting in enhanced hydrogen production through the Mott-Schottky effect [167]. They developed a facile method for constructing a Ru-WO2.72 Mott-Schottky heterojunction, which displays efficient hydrogen evolution in acidic conditions, as shown in Fig. 10(b). This approach employs the hydrogen tungsten bronze compound formed by WO3, facilitating hydrogen transfer from the substrate to the active site. Peng et al. investigated the synthesis of a highly effective Pt2W/WO3/RGO catalyst using a one-step electrochemical approach, as shown in Fig. 10(c) [168]. This catalyst showed exceptional performance in the HER, particularly at high current densities. The Pt2W/WO3/RGO catalyst exhibited a significantly higher current density of 500 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of 394 mV, in comparison to commercial Pt catalysts. This catalyst possesses a potent mix of high activity and the capacity to release hydrogen, making it an innovative material for efficiently producing large amounts of hydrogen with exceptional stability. By employing rational synthesis methodologies and interfacial modification, these catalysts can surpass the constraints of traditional noble metal electrocatalysts, offering an economical and environmentally-friendly approach for converting electrochemical energy. Peng et al. introduced a self-supported electrocatalyst made of porous iron phosphide and tungsten oxide (Fe2P-WO2.92/NF) [82]. The catalyst was generated on NF using a straightforward in-situ growth, etching, and phosphatization method, as shown in Fig. 10(d). The presence of OVs in the catalysts facilitates the transfer of charges between Fe2P and WO2.92, hence improving the catalysts' porosity and the exposing of active sites. The electrochemical investigations demonstrated that the Fe2P-WO2.92/NF catalyst displayed excellent OER performance in alkaline conditions, characterized by minimal overpotentials, small Tafel slopes, enhanced conductivity, and consistent stability. Subsequently, Zhou et al. introduced a self-supported catalyst composed of Ni2P/WO2.83 heterointerface microspheres for the HER in alkaline conditions as shown in Fig. 10(e) [169]. The catalyst effectively addressed the fundamental problems of intrinsic activity, conductivity, and the quantity of active sites by employing heterointerface construction and defect and structural engineering methodologies. The catalyst exhibited exceptional efficacy and durability, surpassing the majority of non-precious metal catalysts documented in alkaline environments. Similarly, Zhang et al. reported a Ni4W/WO3 electrocatalyst for alkaline HER, which was synthesized on NFs with closely connected interfaces through a phase transition, as shown in Fig. 10(f) [170]. The catalyst facilitates the splitting of water molecules through the hydroxyl groups that are tightly attached to the WO3 sites. This enhances the production of hydrogen due to the combined impact of the strong adsorption of hydrogen on the Ni sites. The catalyst demonstrates exceptional performance in the alkaline HER process, with a low overpotential and a good Tafel slope. Xiao et al. reported a catalyst called WO3/Fe2O3-NiO, which is a heterostructured catalyst consisting of tungsten oxide-modified iron-nickel oxide [171]. This catalyst was synthesized on a nickel backbone and used for OER. The heterostructured interface exhibits a substantial concentration of heterometallic-oxygen bridging sites and a plentiful amount of OVs caused by high-valent tungstensates. This augmentation significantly boosts the catalyst's effectiveness in facilitating the oxygen-evolution process. The catalyst demonstrates a small overpotential and excellent stability, making it suitable for efficient and long-lasting OER. Wang et al. employed a two-step hydrothermal synthesis method to produce NiFe-WO3- x /NF [172]. In this context, WO3- x serves as an activation medium, enhancing the overall water-splitting efficiency of NiFe-based electrocatalysts. Another study, employing a similar experimental approach, is dedicated solely to investigating the OER [83]. The process of applying WO x on NF is a widely used technique. WO x exhibits favorable electrocatalytic characteristics and facilitates the electrolysis of water molecules. Subsequently, the electrocatalytic characteristics of the materials can be further enhanced by cultivating nickelides, such as nickel-tungsten alloy (Ni-W) or nickel-tungsten oxide (Ni-W-O) on the surface of WO x [173–175]. The tungsten-nickelide materials demonstrate exceptional catalytic efficiency and durability in electrocatalytic reactions involving HER and OER. By adjusting the composition and arrangement of the alloy, the catalytic performance of the materials can be enhanced to increase the efficiency and selectivity of the catalytic reactions. Tungsten-nickelide compounds have significant catalytic activity in the process of complete hydrolysis, leading to enhanced rates of water splitting and improved electrochemical efficiency. These materials are very suitable for many applications, including HER, OER, and overall water splitting. Zhang et al. designed an environmentally friendly dry chemical route to construct heterostructured CuO/Cu/WO3- x /WO3/W electrocatalysts using ion beam technology [176]. Through H+ beam bombardment, oxygen vacancies were formed in tungsten oxides and simultaneously deposited Cu species on the surface of the oxidized W lattice. This preparation method significantly improved the HER performance of the WO x -based electrocatalysts. The self-supported CuO/Cu/WO3- x /WO3/W electrode exhibited an overpotential 127 mV at −10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4, which was far superior to the other samples without a WO3− x layer or deposited Cu species. The oxygen induced by H+ beam bombardment vacancies enhanced the conductivity of the tungsten oxides by narrowing the band gap and providing a large number of unsaturated W atoms that could be used as active sites. Cu species acted as electron migration facilitators in enhancing the HER activity. This strategy provides a facile way for the construction of transition metal-based heterostructured electrocatalysts. 3.4.2 Core-shell structure The low conductivity of WO x limits the electron transfer and thus reduces the catalytic activity [22]. By forming a carbon shell on the surface of WO x , the conductivity of the catalyst can be increased to improve electron transfer. This increased conductivity helps to speed up the rate of electron transfer, thus improving the catalytic activity. The introduction of carbon shells can also regulate the adsorption capacity on the surface of the catalyst, by which the adsorption capacity can be regulated to optimize the adsorption and dissociation processes of the catalyst on the reactants. In addition, the carbon shell can serve to protect the catalyst from oxidation or other environmental factors. This protective layer can enhance the stability of the catalyst and extend its service life. For example, Jing et al. developed a catalyst with a core-shell structure, namely a carbon-coated WO x /C catalyst (WO x @C/C), which is highly efficient for the HER [177]. The catalyst enhanced electrical conductivity through carbon coating and adjusted the Gibbs free energy values of H* at various adsorption sites. The experimental findings demonstrate that the WO x @C/C catalyst, produced with a metal loading of 40 wt% and heated to 900 °C, exhibits exceptional HER performance and durability, exhibiting catalytic characteristics comparable to Pt-like catalysts. This proposes a novel approach to develop economical and expandable catalysts for the generation of hydrogen. Aerosol processing methods have been extensively employed for catalyst synthesis due to their inherent benefits of simplicity and eco-friendliness. Previous studies have shown that transition metal dihalides such as MoS2 and WS2 have great potential as efficient and low-cost catalysts for HER with their unique structural and electronic properties. The most outstanding contribution to the catalytic activity of HER is made by the edge surface rather than the inert base surface of MoS2 [178] and WS2 [179], i.e., the unsaturated sulfur atoms on the edge play a significant role [180]. Chen et al. developed a method of synthesizing aerosols using a combination of rGO, WS2, and WO3 ternary nanohybrid materials [181]. This method was specifically used for the HER. The materials acquired using this technique possess a globular morphology and are composed of crumpled graphene and WS2/WO3 nanorods. The experimental data demonstrates that the hybrid catalyst displays exceptional electrocatalytic activity for the HER, characterized by a low Tafel slope and onset potential. The synergistic effects of heterojunctions and defect engineering enhance the efficiency of HER. For instance, Kong et al. synthesized hexagonal nanosheets of WS2/WO3− x heterostructures with oxygen vacancies using solvothermal and chemical vapor deposition methods [182]. Li et al. introduced a catalyst consisting of a core-shell structure with CoO@graphitized carbon generated from ZIF-67, which was used for the application of OER [183]. The catalyst was fabricated using a CoO@GC/WO3@CL architecture, which involved enclosing a thin carbon layer. This catalyst demonstrated exceptional catalytic performance. The experimental results indicate that the catalyst exhibits a minimal overpotential during the OER. This catalyst's design is influenced by the ZIFs template, offering a novel approach for constructing multilayer structured OER catalysts. Ni atoms are considered to be extraordinary water splitting centers and their hydroxides and oxides have good water affinity [184]. For example, Zhao et al. prepared a novel defect-rich electrocatalyst, Ni(OH)2/NiO-C/WO3 hierarchical arrays, consisting of a layered array of WO3 cores and Ni(OH)2/NiO shells by using various methods such as hydrothermal method, annealing and electrodeposition, as shown in Fig. 11 (a) [185]. The catalyst consists of a hierarchical array of WO3 cores with large specific surface area and Ni(OH)2/NiO shell layers, thus exposing abundant defect sites. The Ni(OH)2/NiO nanosheets doped with high-valent, large-atom W6+ can easily reform active materials with high intrinsic activity, as well as abundant heterojunction interfaces with discontinuities and perturbations, which are favorable for water splitting. Non-homogeneous catalysts with multiple non-homogeneous interfaces can increase the catalytic activity centers to a certain extent.
