To further enhance the electrocatalytic performance of HER, WO3 has been complexed with other materials such as carbon, metals, and metal-based compounds. The multicomponent catalysts have been prepared through the synergistic effect of each component, which overcomes the instability of the active component in acidic and alkaline electrolytes. For example, Liu et al. prepared WO2-Na x WO3 covered with amorphous FeOOH self-supported on 3D nickel foam (WO2-Na x WO3@FeOOH/NF) catalyst using hydrothermal, annealing, and interfacial construction methods, as shown in Fig. 11(b). The FeOOH coating slowed the lowered corrosion rate and increased active sites with improving stability and activity [186]. The self-supporting structure of the octahedral lattice with flocculated FeOOH provided more channels for electrolyte diffusion, further enhancing the catalyst's activity and stability. Heterogeneous structures and tight junctions between different components can improve intrinsic activity and stability by producing strong interactions and improving charge distribution. Coating tungsten-based materials can facilitate the development of more effective catalysts for sustainable energy applications. The construction of multicomponent catalysts can combine the inherent physicochemical properties of each component to improve the catalyst performance. The carbon-based shell layer possesses a higher electron affinity than transition metal oxides, facilitating the electron transfer from the transition metal oxides to the carbon-based shell layer. Jiang et al. developed a Co5.47N-decorated WO2 hybrid catalyst with carbon encapsulation (denoted as (Co5.47N-WO2)@C/NF) for efficient water splitting, as shown in Fig. 11(c). The catalyst's interfacial electronic structure promoted WO2 conductivity, enabling excellent activity for both HER and OER with small overpotentials [187]. The carbon encapsulation and self-support prevented agglomeration, enabling a low cell voltage of 1.54 V at 10 mA cm−2 for overall water splitting. The catalyst's high active site density contributed to its stability under harsh conditions. Researchers explored coating tungsten-based materials to enhance the stability and activity of tungsten-based catalysts in alkaline media. Zhang et al. reported an integrated mesoporous heterostructure array prepared by a hydrogenation/nitridation-induced in situ growth strategy, as shown in Fig. 11(d) [159]. The heterostructures consist of highly conductive oxygen vacancy-enriched tungsten oxide nitride (Vo-WON) nanorod arrays as the backbone, which are encapsulated by ultrathin nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) nanolayers to form high-quality shell/core NC/Vo-WON heterostructures. It was found that this defect-rich heterostructure array not only enhanced the electrical conductivity and modulated the electronic structure, but also promoted the adsorption and dissociation of reactants and provided a large number of potential active sites. In alkaline media, this mesoporous NC/Vo-WON array exhibits excellent HER performance with a small overpotential and a low Tafel slope. In addition, it exhibits prolonged stability with little loss after 100 h at high current densities. Similarly, Peng et al. reported a catalyst formed by loading 15 nm-thick carbon-based shell-coated tungsten oxide nanorods on nickel foams (CTO/NF) for enhanced electrocatalytic OER [188]. The experimental results showed that compared with pure tungsten oxide and noble-metal-based IrO2 catalysts, the CTO/NF possessed lower overpotentials and Tafel slopes, displaying higher catalytic activity. In addition, the carbon-based shell on the CTO is flexible for electron transfer and provides catalytic active sites that improve reactant adsorption and O–H* bond dissociation, which are critical steps in OER and related reactions. The carbon-based shell also keeps the catalyst as nanospheres with a larger specific surface area, which facilitates OER and related reactions. Li et al. reviewed the applications of nickel nitride as multifunctional materials in energy storage and electrocatalysis, highlighting the enhancement of catalytic activity and stability through electronic structure modulation [189]. This is closely related to the multifunctional applications of WO x -based catalysts, particularly in the synergistic optimization of energy storage and electrocatalysis. Combining carbon materials with WO x can form a composite catalyst that takes full advantage of their respective strengths. Carbon materials can be used as conductive support materials to provide electron transfer pathways and increase the stability of the catalyst [190,191]. Carbon materials, including graphite, carbon nanotubes, and graphene, have good electrical conductivity and chemical stability. Carbon materials can provide electron transfer pathways to facilitate electron transfer and catalytic reactions. In addition, carbon materials have a rich pore structure, providing a large number of active sites for catalytic reactions. WO x can be used as active sites to promote the electrocatalytic reaction. This composite catalyst can significantly improve the efficiency of electrocatalytic HER and OER. It should be noted that the selection and design of carbon materials and WO x should be optimized according to the specific application requirements. Different carbon materials and WO x morphologies, structures, and compositions may have different effects on the electrocatalytic performance. Therefore, when designing and preparing electrocatalytic HER and OER catalysts, factors such as catalytic activity, stability, and cost need to be taken into account to achieve the best performance. 4 Stability considerations for WO x -based electrocatalysts This section examines the significance of stability, the mechanisms of deterioration, and the possibility for improving stability in WO x -based electrocatalysts. The long-term performance and stability of WO x -based electrocatalysts heavily depend on the stability, which is of utmost importance. Gaining comprehension of and effectively dealing with degradation mechanisms is crucial for enhancing their stability. The degradation pathways of electrocatalysts based on WO x involve catalyst detachment from the electrode, support corrosion, impurity deposition on the catalyst, dissolution of active sites, and surface reconstruction. These processes can result in a decline in catalytic activity and deterioration of the electrocatalyst over time. Diverse approaches can be utilized to augment the stability of WO x -based electrocatalysts. These may involve employing rational design and modification techniques to minimize catalyst peeling, utilizing corrosion-resistant support materials, implementing steps to control impurities, preventing the dissolution of active sites, and exercising control over surface reconstruction. Implementing these tactics enhances the stability and durability of WO x -based electrocatalysts, resulting in superior performance in electrochemical applications. 4.1 The significance of stability Stability is a crucial factor in determining a catalyst's capacity to sustain its initial catalytic activity over an extended length of time in the industry. A catalyst's activity and selectivity should be maintained under reaction conditions for a longer period without substantial degradation or deactivation. Generally, the activity, cost, and stability are vital factors for designing electrocatalysts for practical applications [192,193]. Promising candidates with reduced overpotentials and Tafel slopes for electrocatalysis are in demand, while the cost reduction facilitates the commercialization and large-scale application of catalysts. The up-to-date investigation applied a catalyst model to illustrate the importance of electrocatalytic stability in practical applications [194,195]. As shown in Fig. 12 (a), catalyst A started with a higher HER activity but degraded faster; catalyst B was less active in the beginning but decayed slowly. Although the initial HER activity of catalyst B was lower than that of catalyst A, 44% of the energy cost caused by HER could be saved after 1228 h of continuous operation. As investigated in Fig. 12(b), the OER activity at the start-up of catalyst C was higher, but the degradation rate was faster; catalyst D was less active but more stable. Although the initial OER activity of catalyst D was much lower than that of catalyst C, about 48% of the energy cost caused by the OER overpotential could be saved after 2000 h of continuous operation, as shown in Fig. 12(c). As discussed, the long-term stability of catalysts may be more important than considering their activity in practical industrial applications. However, it is rarely emphasized in current electrocatalytic studies. Long-term stability ensures that the catalyst retains good performance in continuous operation, reducing downtime and maintenance costs while improving system reliability and economics. As a result, developing catalysts with strong long-term stability is critical for achieving sustainable industrial applications. 4.2 Stability challenges of WO x -based electrocatalysts Both mechanical and chemical factors influence the stability of a catalyst. The mechanical stability of the system is influenced by both the adhesive strength between the catalyst and the electrode substrate, and the stresses caused by the generation of oxygen bubbles. Chemical stability pertains to the capacity of the catalyst and support material to withstand oxidation or corrosion resulting from high oxidation potentials and intense acidic conditions [196]. The limited catalytic durability of WO x -based electrocatalysts is primarily due to the inadequate chemical and electrochemical stability of the electroactive components, catalyst aggregation, mechanical instability, leaching of the active noble metals, and corrosion of the supports in highly acidic and alkaline environments. The following tactics can be used to improve catalyst durability: selection of stable electroactive components, optimization of catalyst structural design, insertion of stability enhancers or protective layers, improvement of support stability, and strong metal-carrier interactions and metal alloying can be used to strengthen the catalyst's durability and stability to resist deactivation [194,197,198]. To produce longer-lasting catalytic performance, these strategies strive to improve the chemical stability, electrochemical stability, mechanical stability, and corrosion resistance of the catalysts. 4.2.1 Catalyst detachment from the electrode The development of electrocatalysts with low-cost materials, industrially relevant activity, and long-term durability is desperately needed but remains difficult at this time. A mixture of mechanical and chemical factors influences the stability of the catalyst [196]. The strength of the link between the catalyst and the electrode substrate as well as the stresses caused by oxygen bubbles have an impact on mechanical stability. Chemical stability refers to the catalyst's and carrier's capacity to withstand oxidation or corrosion in high oxidation potential and acidic environments. The adhesion strength between the catalyst and the electrode substrate plays a crucial role in guaranteeing the stability of the catalyst. Ionomer binders, such as Nafion, are frequently employed to facilitate the uniform distribution and immobilization of the catalyst at the interface between the electrode and electrolyte [199]. Nevertheless, the mechanical toughness of the membrane electrode may be diminished due to the chemical degradation of the ionomer binder. Therefore, it is imperative to develop superior ionomer binders or employ alternative interfacial modification techniques to enhance stability [200]. The catalyst's mass loading is also a significant topic of concern. Overloading can lead to insufficient contact between the catalyst and the electrode, increasing the likelihood of stripping during operation. Hence, it is necessary to determine the ideal loading of the catalyst to achieve a proper equilibrium between adhesion strength and catalytic activity. Furthermore, scientists are investigating alternative approaches to enhance the bonding force and durability between the catalyst and the electrode substrate. An effective method involves incorporating cross-linking agents to improve adhesion qualities through the cross-linking of catalyst particles or the formation of a cross-linking network [201]. This enhances the stability of the catalyst and minimizes the likelihood of stripping. Furthermore, intercalation materials show great potential as a focus of research. The introduction of an intercalation material between the catalyst and the electrode substrate enhances the interfacial interaction and improves the adhesion strength [202]. This objective can be accomplished by carefully choosing appropriate intercalation materials and refining the intercalation procedure. Various techniques, such as ionomer binders, loading control, cross-linkers, and intercalation materials, can enhance the adhesion qualities between the catalyst and the electrode substrate. Ongoing research in this field presents ample opportunities for advancement. 4.2.2 Corrosion of the support Traditional carrier materials like carbon and TMOs are prone to dissolution, passivation, or oxidation under acidic and oxidizing conditions, which can result in the deterioration of the catalyst carriers and a decline in catalytic efficiency [188]. In extremely acidic and oxidizing conditions, carbon carriers can undergo oxidative damage, resulting in a reduction in their conductivity characteristics. TMOs, when used as carrier materials, are prone to oxidation and corrosion, particularly at high potentials. This leads to a decrease in their ability to immobilize catalysts and conduct electricity [65]. The oxidation or delamination of these carriers results in a reduction of the conductive pathway connecting the catalyst and the electrode. This leads to a drop in the number of active sites and a decrease in the conductivity of the entire catalyst layer [203]. Furthermore, the movement, crumpling, and corrosion of the carrier material might undermine the adhesion of the active component, resulting in further particle migration, agglomeration, clustering, and even segregation. These consequences result in a decrease in catalytic efficiency, which includes the depletion of active sites and the uneven distribution of the catalyst layer [72]. To address these issues, researchers are currently investigating novel catalyst carrier materials with enhanced resistance to corrosion and improved stability. For instance, certain nanostructured materials like boron nitride exhibit exceptional resistance to acids and oxidation, demonstrating high stability in acidic and oxidizing surroundings [204]. Furthermore, carbon-based carrier materials possessing exceptional electrical conductivity and chemical stability, such as the introduction of N and F atoms into the graphene structure can modulate the electronic structure and chemical properties of graphene. N and F doping can introduce additional charge transfer and polarity effects, resulting in better catalytic activity and selectivity on the graphene surface. In addition, N and F doping can enhance the interaction between graphene and WO x -based electrocatalysts and promote the adhesion and stability of the catalyst [205,206]. Surface modification and functionalization are effective ways to enhance the stability of carrier materials. To enhance the stability of the carrier material, a protective or modification layer can be applied to its surface, preventing direct exposure to acids and oxides in the surrounding environment. Ultimately, while choosing catalyst carrier materials, it is crucial to consider their capacity to withstand corrosion and maintain stability in both acidic and oxidizing situations. Enhancing the stability and performance of catalysts can be achieved through the advancement of carrier materials and surface modification techniques. Nevertheless, additional investigation and examination are still required for particular applications and practical systems. 4.2.3 Impurities deposition on catalyst The stability of WO x -based electrocatalysts can be influenced by degrading mechanisms, with the deposition of contaminants on the surface of the catalyst having a significant impact. Impurities can cause the catalyst to become less stable and operate poorly, resulting in decreased catalytic activity and accelerated degradation rates. Accumulating contaminants can obstruct or pollute the active area of the catalyst, therefore impeding the progress of the catalytic reaction [207]. This could lead to a decline in catalytic activity and a drop in electrochemical performance. Impurities can modify the surface chemistry and structural characteristics of the catalyst, thereby impacting its electrical properties and catalytic behavior [208]. The content and characteristics of the impurities adhered to the catalyst can differ based on the specific reaction conditions and the origin of the impurities [209]. Various impurities, such as carbonaceous species, metal ions, sulfides, and other organic or inorganic pollutants, can have an impact on electrocatalysts based on WO x . The existence of these impurities might originate from various origins, including the reaction conditions, the raw materials, or the method used to create the catalyst. Romanov et al. described a technique known as radical-enhanced atomic layer deposition (REALD) to produce WO x thin films with precise amounts of oxygen deficit [210]. The study found that the process had saturable characteristics in terms of precursor dose and reactive oxygen exposure time, namely within a temperature range of 200–300 °C. Additionally, the process achieved a high level of deposition uniformity on economically significant substrates. The researchers acquired precise control over the level of hypoxia in the films by adjusting the precursor dosage and reactive oxygen exposure duration during the REALD process. This control is crucial for managing the electrical and optical properties of the films. Chanyeon et al. discovered that N-doped carbon catalysts can activate themselves when Fe impurities are present. Furthermore, these catalysts demonstrate exceptional stability for a duration of 120 h [211]. This study focuses on the issue of significant catalyst deactivation caused by minute amounts of trace metal contaminants in ultra-pure electrolyte solutions. This novel and adaptable technique has important implications for the production of long-lasting catalysts, particularly for processes that are susceptible to deactivation due to metal impurities. Additionally, studies conducted in the field of nanostructure growth by Sheng et al. showed that extraordinarily long nanowires from the triclinic crystal system Na5W14O44 and the monoclinic crystal system WO3 could be produced by heating a tungsten source in a low oxygen pressure environment [212]. The results also show that residue deposition during nanowire growth has a major effect on the size, composition, and morphology of the nanowires. These results suggest that the composition and structure of the nanostructures are highly dependent on the purity of the feedstock and the thermal characteristics of the impurities. Additionally, the growth of nanowires can be enhanced by residue deposition, which is caused by the localized vapor pressure generated by the residue. 4.2.4 Dissolution of active sites By sensible design and modification, it is possible to decrease the deactivation of active sites, avoid the leaching of electroactive components, limit catalyst aggregation, raise the mechanical strength of catalysts, and improve catalytic stability in acidic and alkaline environments. These steps will help to increase the service life and dependability of HER electrocatalysts [213–215]. The dissolution of active sites is a critical factor that can greatly affect the stability of WO x -based electrocatalysts. To address this problem, researchers have concentrated on rational design and modification strategies. For example, Song et al. exhibited a two-step synthetic procedure for creating self-assembled WO3·0.33H2O nanoflowers using a dissolution and regeneration technique [216]. The nanoflowers' distinct morphologies were achieved by precisely regulating parameters such as temperature, solvent, and reaction duration. The nanoflowers displayed both a localized surface plasmon resonance effect and a significant photocatalytic activity due to the presence of W5+ ions and the unique shape. In addition, the WO3·0.33H2O nanoflowers exhibited a potential for gas sensors, demonstrating excellent selectivity and linearity towards acetone vapor within a particular concentration range. Ensuring that electroactive components do not leach out is an important factor in improving the stability and performance of WO x -based electrocatalysts. Guo et al. examined the pH response characteristics of tungsten/tungsten oxide electrodes fabricated using various techniques [217]. The immersion of the electrodes in HNO3 solution was deemed unsatisfactory due to their propensity to exfoliate or dissolve during testing. However, alternate preparation procedures demonstrated a consistent and predictable sensitivity to changes in pH, as well as exceptional durability when used for extended periods of potential monitoring. Heat treatment proved to be the most efficient technique, leading to a reduced rate of dissolution and the creation of a dense oxide film on the surface of the electrode. The heat-treated electrodes have these attributes, rendering them the optimal selection for extended monitoring purposes. The aggregation of catalysts can impede the performance of materials based on tungsten oxide, thus requiring the implementation of measures to prevent this occurrence. Thalgaspitiya et al. described the production of mesoporous, multi-valent tungsten oxide with a remarkable surface area by a unique method involving metal dissolution combined with reverse micelle creation [218]. The utilization of this approach resulted in the production of mesoporous WO x with the most elevated surface area. Consequently, it possesses excellent properties as a heterogeneous catalyst for the oxidation of organosulfur compounds found in crude oil. The catalyst demonstrated exceptional efficacy, accomplishing full oxidation of dibenzothiophene rapidly at ambient temperature. Moreover, the catalyst demonstrated the potential to be used again for several reaction cycles without a noticeable activity decay. Ultimately, WO x -based electrocatalysts can be made far more effective and capable by using logical planning and modification strategies. These materials can exhibit improved durability and dependability by addressing problems including active site degradation, preventing electroactive component leaching, preventing catalyst aggregation, and improving mechanical strength and stability. This chapter's examples provide helpful insights into the potential for logical design and modification to fully utilize the potential of WO x -based electrocatalyst stability in a variety of applications, such as environmental sensing, energy conversion and storage, electrocatalytic HER and OER, and catalysis. 4.2.5 Surface reconstruction Surface reconstruction is vital for the catalytic efficiency of WO x -based electrocatalysts. The alteration of the catalyst's surface during the OER can have a substantial effect on its performance and durability. Comprehending and using surface reconstruction have emerged as crucial study domains for enhancing the efficiency of these catalysts [195,196]. Diverse techniques have been utilized to accomplish the surface reconstruction of electrocatalysts predicated on WO x . Šedivá et al. employed physical vapor deposition in a reactive environment of atomic oxygen to fabricate well-organized tungsten oxide thin films on a Cu(110) substrate [219]. This alignment was achieved through the reconstruction of the copper substrate driven by oxygen. Bai et al. introduced a novel assembly technique utilizing orientated attachment and reconstruction for the sonochemical synthesis of microspheres composed of nanosheets [220]. The obtained samples displayed a nano/microstructure that had a hierarchical porosity and a non-stoichiometric composition. These characteristics make them very suitable for use in sensing materials and gas diffusion applications. In addition, Li et al. examined W18O49 and its non-stoichiometric structure, which allowed for the creation of OVs in close proximity to low-valence W atoms [221]. The researchers employed cooperative techniques that incorporated Mo doping and plasma-induced surface reconstruction to augment the oxidative desulfurization activity of W18O49. The addition of Mo species and the application of plasma bombardment to the surface led to the creation of reactive sites with reduced coordination numbers and enhanced OVs, consequently enhancing the catalytic activity. The catalytic efficacy of WO x -based electrocatalysts is influenced by multiple parameters during surface rebuilding. Surface reconstruction can modify the active sites, resulting in alterations in both the catalytic activity and selectivity. By altering the electrical and atomic configuration of the catalyst surface, it is possible to generate novel active sites or adjust the affinity of reactants, consequently impacting the overall efficiency of catalysis. Moreover, the catalytic activity can be greatly improved by the existence of OVs caused by surface reconstruction. These openings offer advantageous locations for the adsorption and activation of molecules involved in chemical reactions, hence enhancing the efficiency of catalytic processes. The concentration and arrangement of OVs are crucial factors in influencing the catalytic efficiency of the reconstituted catalyst. To summarize, the process of surface reconstruction has a substantial impact on the catalytic efficiency of electrocatalysts WO x -based electrocatalysts. The alteration of active sites and the existence of OVs caused by surface reconstruction are crucial factors in determining the overall catalytic efficiency and selectivity. Researchers can improve the performance and stability of WO x -based electrocatalysts for energy conversion, environmental remediation, and chemical synthesis by comprehending and managing surface reconstruction. 4.3 Potential for stability enhancement of WOx-based electrocatalysts TMO materials, such as NiO, MnO x , CoO x , and WO3, have a wide range of potential applications in a wide range of electrochemical electrode materials [222]. During electrochemical reactions, the chemical bonds between metals and oxygen (M–O) are affected. In addition, the instability of M–O bonding seriously affects the stability of TMOs under the effect of an electrochemical field [223]. The WO x -based electrocatalysts have a maximum testing stability time of 780 h at 10 mA cm−2 for OER as shown in Fig. 13 . However, compared with other electrocatalytic materials (e.g., layered double hydroxides and noble-metal-based catalytic materials) that have the stability of thousands of hours, the stability of WO x presents a substantial opportunity for further enhancement. The electrocatalytic process may include numerous cycles of oxidation and reduction due to the poor stability of WO x . Such cycles may result in changes to the catalyst's surface's physical and chemical characteristics, including modifications to the crystal structure, the development of surface defects, and the deactivation of the active sites, which may decrease the catalyst's stability. Cyclic voltammetry, chronopotentiometry, and chronoamperometry methods are frequently used stability testing techniques [224,225]. Researchers can also experiment with new techniques to judge catalyst stability, such as flow cell-inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry and differential electrochemical mass spectrometry [226,227]. These techniques can give insight into the variables affecting stability and can precisely identify the catalyst's disintegration during the reaction. To satisfy the requirements for industrial applications, HER electrocatalysts must exhibit current densities exceeding 200 mA cm−2 [102], whereas OER electrocatalysts necessitate current densities surpassing 500 mA cm−2 and overpotentials below 300 mV [228]. Presently, most WO x -based catalysts investigated in laboratory settings demonstrate current densities ranging from 10 to 100 mA cm−2. Notably, the Ni2P/WO2.83/NF heterointerface in WO x -based HER electrocatalysts exhibits stability for 50 h at 1 A cm−2 [169]. Similarly, HER electrocatalysts with monatomic Pt loading on a monolayer of WO3 demonstrate stability for up to 150 h at 200 mA cm−2 [135]. Notably, FeWO4, featuring a wolframite crystal structure, exhibits the synergistic advantages of tungsten and iron oxide, thereby demonstrating superior characteristics [229]. A FeWO4-WO3/NF heterostructure catalyst was synthesized using hydrothermal and calcination methods, demonstrating excellent OER activity and stability under high current density and alkaline conditions, attributed to high electrical conductivity and interfacial electron redistribution., maintaining stability for up to 100 h at 1 A cm−2 [230]. Additionally, in WO x -based OER electrocatalysts, the nitrogen-doped carbon layer encapsulates tungsten nitride containing oxygen vacancies and exhibits stability for 100 h at 200 mA cm−2 [159]. The crystal structure and defects of WO x also play an important role in the stability of the catalyst. Lattice defects and structural defects may lead to inactivation of active sites or an increase in the solubility of the catalyst, thus reducing its stability. In addition, WO x may undergo thermal decomposition or crystal phase transition under high-temperature conditions, leading to the destruction of the catalyst structure and inactivation of the active sites. Therefore, the stability of WO x catalysts may be limited when applied under high-temperature conditions. IrO x -based catalysts with more defects and vacancies can lead to higher dissolution rates, possibly because these metal vacancies can introduce more lattice oxygen exchange, leading to an unstable crystal structure [231]. Therefore, it is not the case that the more WO x with defects, the better the stability. The WO x electrocatalysts may undergo oxidation reactions at high temperatures, especially in oxidizing environments. This high-temperature oxidation reaction may lead to the formation of an oxide layer on the surface of the catalyst, which hinders the exposure of catalytic active sites and the adsorption of reactants, thus reducing the activity and stability of the catalyst. Under high oxidation potential conditions, oxidation reactions may occur on the catalyst surface, leading to the dissociation of some catalyst atoms from the surface and their dissolution into the electrolyte [10,195]. Under strong acid or base conditions, the surface acid-base properties of the catalyst may change, leading to the inactivation of the active sites or rearrangement of the surface sites [232]. Impurities in the electrolyte can affect the stability of HER and OER. Most current studies use ultrapure or deionized water to prepare electrolytes, primarily to exclude the effects of impurities to more accurately study the effects of specific factors on performance [233]. This can reduce the stability and activity of the WO x catalyst. The active components of the WO x electrocatalyst may dissolve into the electrolyte, leading to a decrease in catalyst activity. Dissolution and leaching phenomena may be caused by the solubility of the electrocatalyst material itself or by electrochemical reaction conditions. 5 Conclusions and outlooks Currently, the research on WO x in the HER and OER is primarily at the theoretical stage, and it has not yet been widely applied in industrial settings. Acquiring a thorough understanding of the modification strategy, mechanism, and stability of WO x -based electrocatalysts is essential. This understanding should include the catalytic mechanism of WO x and its practical industrial stability. Key challenges and future directions in the activation strategy of WO x must be addressed. To speed up the electrocatalytic process, it's crucial to optimize the catalyst's electrical conductivity by adjusting its band energy levels and increasing electron numbers in the conduction band. The electrocatalytic performance of WO x -based catalysts depends on the adsorption capacity of intermediates at active sites, which can be improved by modifying surface characteristics and conductivity. Lowering adsorption energy enhances catalytic efficiency by reducing excess potential. The electron density at active sites, influenced by polarization within orbital coupling, boosts chemical adsorption capability. Further research is needed to understand oxygen vacancy formation, identify active sites, and improve the electrochemical stability of WO x materials. Despite progress in developing WO x -based electrocatalysts, there's still a significant gap between laboratory research and industrial applications. This gap can be bridged by pursuing the following directions. To visually summarize these potential research directions, methods, and expectations, refer to Fig. 14 . (i) Investigate the dynamic changes in catalytic reactions and the mechanisms behind oxygen vacancies in tungsten oxide. Optimize preparation and structural manipulation techniques to improve catalyst efficiency and durability. Systematic material design and synthesis are needed for catalysts with high activity and durability. (ii) Conduct in-depth studies of WO x -based electrocatalysis mechanisms and achieve long-term stability at high current densities. Advanced in-situ characterization techniques (e.g., Ambient-Pressure X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (AP-XPS), Electrochemical Liquid Transmission Electron Microscopy (EC-LTEM), Mössbauer spectroscopy (MS), Raman Spectroscopy, X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), XAFS, Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR), Spherical Aberration Corrected Transmission Electron Microscope (AC-TEM), Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA), Positron Annihilation Lifetime Spectra (PALS) and Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR)) are crucial for monitoring catalyst transformations. DFT calculations can provide detailed information on intermediate adsorption energies and potential reaction mechanisms. These methods are essential for understanding the relationship between electronic structure and catalytic properties. (iii) Develop and optimize catalysts to achieve industrially relevant current densities (>200 mA cm−2). Current WO x -based catalysts show promising results, but further research is needed to reduce overpotential and extend stability time. High current density and long operating times are essential for industrial-scale hydrogen production. Addressing challenges such as bubble formation, mass transportation obstruction, and catalyst deactivation under extreme conditions is critical. (iv) Explore the industrial application of WO x -based electrocatalysts in seawater electrolysis. This approach leverages abundant marine resources for efficient hydrogen production and seawater desalination. Developing highly active HER and OER catalysts that resist hypochlorite formation and chloride corrosion under alkaline conditions is essential. Enhancing long-term stability under high current densities is a significant engineering goal. Overcoming challenges such as corrosion, impurity accumulation, and reduced catalytic activity in high-salt environments requires dedicated efforts from researchers. Crosnier, Electrochem. Commun. 120 (2020) 106834. Shuang Yu received her Bachelor's degree in Chemical Engineering and Technology from Qiqihar University, China, in 2021. She is currently pursuing her Master's degree in Materials and Chemical Engineering at Zhengzhou University under the supervision of Professor Jin You Zheng. Her research interests primarily focus on the preparation, mechanisms, modifications, and stability of tungsten oxide-based electrocatalysts for water splitting and their related electrochemical applications. Xiaomei Yu received her BS degree in Applied Chemistry (2011) from Henan Institute of Science and Technology, China, and her PhD degree in Applied Chemistry (2011-2017) from Ajou University, South Korea, under the guidance of Prof. Yu Kwon Kim. Since December 2017, she has worked in the School of Chemical Engineering at Zhengzhou University, China. Her current research interest focuses on the fabrication of electro-/photo-catalysts for sustainable energy conversion applications. Huijing Yang received her BS degree in Chemical Engineering and Technology from Henan University of Technology, China (2021). She is currently pursuing her MS degree in Chemical Technology at Zhengzhou University under the supervision of Prof. Jin You Zheng. Her research interests are mainly focused on the preparation of the WO3-based transition metal oxide films by spin-coating, electrodeposition and hydrothermal methods, and the fabrication of photoelectrocatalysts for water splitting. Feng Li is a professor in Institute of Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences. He mainly works on energy materials for lithium ion batteries, lithium–sulfur batteries and electrochemical capacitors. He has published more 350 papers on peer-reviewed journals, such as Energy & Environmental Science, Adv. Mater., etc. with more 66 000 citations and H-index about 110. He obtained the award of National Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars by National Foundation of Science, China and Highly Cited Researcher at Materials by Clarivate Analytics. Songjie Li has been working in Zhengzhou University since 2014, and obtained her PhD degree in Materials Science from University of Science and Technology Beijing, China and National Institute for Materials Science (NIMS), Japan as Joint training of doctoral students in 2010. Following that, she conducted postdoctoral research at NIMS (2011-2014). Her current research focuses on the water splitting, electrochemical corrosion, hydrogen embrittlement, and hydrogen barrier coatings. Young Soo Kang is a professor in Korea Institute of Energy Technology (KENTECH) since February 2022. He received the BSc and the MSc degree in Chemistry Department of Pusan National University, Busan, Korea in 1984 and 1986 and Ph.D. degrees from University of Houston, U.S.A in 1992, postdoctoral fellow at University of California at Berkeley and Stanford University, respectively, for his work on Nanomaterials and Surfactant Related Materials Chemistry. He worked in Pukyong National University from 1995 to 2008 and in Sogang University from 2008 to 2022. Current research interests are focused on the synthesis and application of nanostructured materials for IT and Energy Related Fields. Jin You Zheng received his BS degree in Chemical Engineering and Technology (2009) from Yanbian University, China, and his MS and PhD degrees in Chemistry (2010-2018) from Sogang University, South Korea, under the guidance of Prof. Young Soo Kang. Since July 2018, he has worked in the School of Chemical Engineering at Zhengzhou University, China. His current research interest focuses on the fabrication of electro-/photo-catalysts for energy and environmental applications such as water splitting, CO2 reduction, electrochromic application, and pollutant degradation.

coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalysis plays a crucial role in the field of clean energy conversion and provides essential support for the development of eco-friendly technology. There is a pressing need for electrocatalysts in renewable energy systems that exhibit exceptional activity, selectivity, stability, and economic viability. The utilization of metal oxides as electrocatalysts for the process of water splitting has made substantial progress in both theoretical and practical aspects and has emerged as a widely explored field of research. Tungsten oxides (WO x ) have attracted much attention and are regarded as a highly promising electrocatalytic material due to their exceptional electrocatalytic activity, cost-effectiveness, and ability to withstand extreme conditions. This review introduces the fundamental mechanism of WO x -based electrocatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction and the oxygen evolution reaction, providing a comprehensive overview of recent research advancements in their modification. Factors contributing to the catalytic activity and stability of WO x are explored, highlighting their potential for industrial applications. The aim herein is to provide guidelines for the design and fabrication of WO x -based electrocatalysts, thereby facilitating further research on their mechanistic properties and stability improvements in water splitting.
